climbs.name: Tongulation
climbs.fa: Bob D'Antonio, Rick Thompson, Rob Turan, & Carl Samples

content.description:
Pretty sustained climbing with a fun move at the roof. Climb up the right side around the roof for 11a, direct up from 5th bolt for 11d.

For the 5.11a variation, move right at the bolt just before the roof, not at the roof itself. The 5.11d variation goes straight up, but both "pull" the roof at the same point where they meet up again.

climbs.name: Tasty Flake
climbs.fa: Kevin and Kenny Parker, Dan Caldwell 1987

content.description:
An excellent layback flake with great protection.  This would be a great climb for a trad leader breaking into the grade.

Climb the flake to the anchors.
content.protection: Hand sizes and smaller.  Shuts at the top.
content.location: Right of the Michelin Man area about a hundred yards.

content.description: Climb the bolted crack in the corner to a leftward traverse that leads to a ledge with anchors.
content.location: To the left of Czech Vacation.

content.description:
Some nice climbing split by a good rest (ledge).  Layback up the broken corner and short flake (crux) to ledge.  Finish up gray face (5.8) to anchors.  Alert belay is vital for the final section off the ledge.

Beware of large, loose blocks.
content.location: First route in the Keine Kraft Area

content.description: Climb the rippled face with interesting features similar to Michelin Man.  At about the half way mark, an easier variation can be found by heading into the offwidth located in the right facing corner.  This avoids the crux, so don't follow the chalk into here!  Most of the holds are slopers or small crimps.  Cool climb!  This climb is shaded in the summer until about 12 PM.
content.location: If you can find Michelin Man, this climb is located upstream and to the right of a large right facing corner.

content.description: The route begins below the left side of a roof.  Head up towards the roof and then move up and left following a crack system into an open book corner.  Continue up and right past a tree.  This will be the crux, especially if you do not grab the tree.
content.protection:
Cams .3-2, Small and Medium nuts. A few slings.

No bolts, anchors or fixed gear.
content.location:
This route is to the right of the sport route radial rimmed.

Belay from a large tree on top.  Either rap the tree or lower to the radial rimmed anchor and rap from there.

content.description: Climb a slabby face with varied movement including a fun "heel at your face" rock over move.
Start in a little corner to gain a ledge and the first bolt. Climb bulges to a sloper at the fourth bolt. The fifth bolt and anchors are shared with A-Pocket-Leaps-Now.
Climb Michelin Man to the sixth bolt (after the pocket move) and head right to, you guessed it, a couple of reachy face moves! Just as good, if not better than the left finish.

climbs.name: Michelin Man
climbs.fa: Eric Horst, Stuart Pregnall, Rich Cunningham 1988

content.description:
Definitely the best route on the wall, and one of the best of the grade at Bubba City!

Start with several big moves on small slopers/crimps, which lead to an overhanging section with good holds.  Score a great double-handjam rest, pull an awesome move to a good pocket, and head left at the 6th bolt for the 11d finish (the right bolt line is harder).  Finish on very cool white rock.
content.location: This obvious line is left of a wide crack and the climb Radial Rimmed.  In the summer, it is shaded in the morning and late afternoon (the shiny white face near the top would make it hard to climb in full sun!).

content.description: Climb the left side of the arete pulling through some technical compression moves and high steps.  Wander right of the arete, back left, and finally right again to anchors shared with Exobubba.  This route has some good climbing on it, but the slab on the left side of the arete tends to stay dirty, it's a bit run out, and 2 of the bolts are questionable.
content.protection: 3 bolts to shared open shut anchors.  The first bolt is a 3/8-inch wedge anchor that looks to be in pretty good condition.  The second two look to be well rusted 8mm self drives.  Falling on either wouldn't be advisable, but the route is easily TR'ed after climbing Exobubba.

climbs.name: Likm√©
climbs.fa: Eric Horst, Rick Thompson, Carl Samples, Bob Rentka

content.description:
Start up the easy slightly slopey jug-rails to a sharp handle left and below the first bolt. Zig zag up on techy, crimpy face climbing to anchors below the wall.

Looks like it could stay dry in non-torrential rain.
content.protection:
5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.

Start's pretty easy, but could stick clip.
content.location: Just right of a round arete. On the same short wall and left of Tongulation. Roof above.

content.description: Work up a short crack to reach buckets next to the prominent pancake flake.  Pull the roof (crux) and move up the crack to a stance.  Step right and continue up much easier moves, finishing back left to anchors below the large roof.
content.location: Starts at the obvious crack beside a small boulder

content.description: Great route that climbs through multiple roofs with good holds.
content.location: To the right and around the corner from Let Them Eat Pancakes.

content.description: Stick clip one. Grab some jugs and work your way up. Sequential moves down low brings you to some epic moves near the chains. Super fun!
content.location: just left of let them eat pancake

content.description: This is a nice sustained face climb that may stay dry in a light rain.  Either stick clip the second bolt, or back clean the first bolt after clipping the second.  Pull some steep moves through the roof to get established on the face.  Set up on 2 little razor blades and grit your teeth while pulling to the next hold.  As the angle backs off, make some fun reaches between good holds and some balancy moves on little slopey holds to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 or 5 bolts to open shuts shared with Lycroscopic.
content.location: On the left side of the brown face with a cap roof about 50 ft left of Tongulation.

content.description: Climb seam and bulge and then continue up and right on the smooth face to a horizontal.  Hand traverse right about 6 feet and finish up juggy rock to a ledge with anchors.
content.location: Start 15 feet right of large right facing corner (Smoking Crack).

content.description: Climb past the roof resting on the bench along the way if you'd like, then work your way up and left to the blunt arete.  Make a slightly hard clip, and then figure out beta for the crux that fits your height.  Don't get tempted out left onto the dirty slab.  Follow the left side of the arete past a few insecure moves to the anchors.
content.protection: about 5 bolts to open shut anchors.(can be used to quickly clean the Attacktician)
content.location: First bolted line right of the Prickly Bubba corner.

content.description: Terrible route. The opening moves aren't that bad, but after the first 15 feet this route turns to pure crap. After the 3rd bolt there aren't any holds so I had to traverse left to the edge and use a tree to get up and over to the shuts. Don't climb this. At All.
content.location: To the left of Michelin Man.

content.description: Climb up into the shallow corner clipping the shiny new bolts and ignoring the old pin.  Pull through a series of tenuous slab moves to a ledge below the aesthetic arete (may feel hard if it hasn't been climbed in a while).  Make some fun moves up the left side of the arete and swing around right to the anchor just before the top.
content.location: The route climbs the sharp arete just right of the big roof.

content.description: Begin on the right side of the white, blunt arete and finish at the shared anchor.
A fight from start to finish. Interesting cryptic moves comprise this short bouldery climb. It's not over until you reach the chains!
content.location: Can be accessed by climbing up route to the right in order to work moves on top rope.
